It is common for hazardous landslides and debris flows to occur in California after heavy rain when the ground is saturated. âThe rainy season begins in California around late November or early December, but the landslide season for unburned areas is delayed by about a month until the ground has really gotten wet,â said Jonathan Godt, USGS Landslide Hazards Program Coordinator. âThe areas of greatest concern now are areas of steep terrain that have been subject to wildfires in the past 1-2 years that get hit with heavy rain.â While it probably hasnât been raining enough yet this year for deeply seated landslides or debris flows to start outside the burn areas, itâs never too soon to be prepared and understand when and why these events occur. USGS conducts scientific studies in several areas related to landslides, climate, and wildfire. [caption id="" align="alignright" width="468"] Just after midnight, on March 8, 2010, a large rockfall incident hit I-70 in Glenwood Canyon, near mile marker 125 just west of Hanging Lake Tunnel, near the city of Glenwood Springs, Colorado.[/caption] Among other things, landslides and debris flows can be triggered by various events including earthquakes and heavy rainfall; and as noted above, they are especially problematic in areas where wildfires have occurred. The National Weather Service provides landslide warnings based on criteria the USGS and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration developed for hazard assessments in areas burned by wildfires. âThe key thing for the public is to listen to the [National Weather Service],â said USGS research hydrologist Jason Kean. âThe weather service is tracking the rainfall and itâs the rainfall intensity that triggers these things; so they can use the radar and networks of rain gauges to decide when the rainfall intensity is getting close to the threshold that triggers the debris flows.â
